<div style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><hr size="1" width="160" noshade color="black" align="left" style="width:120.0pt;"></div>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">*</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Leased
property</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In addition to the above, Abbott has manufacturing
facilities in six other locations in the United States, including Puerto Rico.
Outside the United States, manufacturing facilities are located in thirteen
other countries. Abbott&#146;s facilities are deemed suitable and provide adequate
productive capacity.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:18.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">15</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='15',FILE='C:\fc\5213854384_D11263_1741329\1583-1-dk.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Feb 21 13:09 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In the United States, including Puerto Rico, Abbott
owns nine distribution centers. Outside the United States, Abbott owns ten
distribution centers. Abbott also has twenty-one United States research and
development facilities located at: Abbott Park, Illinois; Alameda, California;
Austin, Texas; Columbus, Ohio (two locations); Cranbury, New Jersey; Des
Plaines, Illinois; East Windsor, New Jersey; Fairfield, California; Golden,
Colorado; Hollywood, Florida; Irving, Texas; Long Grove, Illinois; North
Chicago, Illinois; Parsippany, New Jersey; Redwood City, California; Santa
Clara, California; South Brunswick, New Jersey; Temecula, California; Weston,
Florida; and Worcester, Massachusetts. Outside the United States, Abbott has
research and development facilities in Australia, Belgium, Canada, France,
Germany, Ireland, Japan, the Netherlands, South Africa, Spain, Switzerland, and
the United Kingdom.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Except as noted, the
corporate offices, and those principal plants in the United States listed
above, are owned by Abbott or subsidiaries of Abbott. The remaining
manufacturing plants and all other facilities are owned or leased by Abbott or
subsidiaries of Abbott. There are no material encumbrances on the properties.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 47.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-47.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ITEM&nbsp;3.</font></b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>LEGAL
PROCEEDINGS<a name="Item3_LegalProceedings_100834"></a></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Abbott is involved in various claims, legal
proceedings and investigations, including (as of January&nbsp;31, 2007) those
described below.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Six cases are pending in which Abbott seeks to enforce
its patents relating to divalproex sodium (a drug that Abbott sells under the
trademark Depakote&#174;). In one case (filed December&nbsp;2006 in the U.S.
District Court for the Central District of California), Abbott seeks injunctive
relief against Anchen Pharmaceuticals,&nbsp;Inc. and Anchen International
Pharmaceuticals Company, Ltd. and their proposed generic version of
extended-release Depakote&#174;. In two of the actions (filed in November&nbsp;2005
and April&nbsp;2006, respectively) pending in the U.S. District Court for the
Northern District of Illinois, Abbott seeks injunctive relief against Mylan
Pharmaceuticals&#146; proposed generic version of extended-release Depakote&#174;. Abbott
filed two other cases (June&nbsp;2005 and May&nbsp;2006) in the U.S. District
Court for the Northern District of Illinois against Nu-Pharm Inc., Apotex Inc.,
and Apotex Corp. relating to generic versions of delayed-release Depakote&#174;.
These actions are currently stayed while Apotex appeals a decision enjoining the
approval of Nu-Pharm&#146;s ANDA. The sixth case against Alra Laboratories,&nbsp;Inc.
(filed in August&nbsp;1992 in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District
of Illinois) relates to a generic version of delayed-release Depakote&#174;.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">One case was pending in the United States District
Court for the Eastern District of Texas, <i>Chiron
Corporation and Rockefeller University v. Abbott and Centocor, </i>involving
patents regarding monoclonal antibodies, which plaintiffs claimed covered
adalimumab (a drug sold by Abbott under the trademark Humira&#174;). The litigation
was resolved through binding arbitration.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Six cases are pending related to Abbott&#146;s patents for
sevoflurane (an anesthesia product Abbott sells under the trademarks Ultane&#174;
and Sevorane&#174;). Two cases brought by Abbott and Central Glass Company, Ltd.
(Central Glass) against Baxter Healthcare Corporation (Baxter) are pending in
the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois and
allege that Baxter&#146;s proposed generic sevoflurane product infringes their
patent(s). In one of those cases, the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals held one
of Abbott&#146;s patents invalid. One case, filed by Baxter and Baxter Healthcare
Ltd. in June&nbsp;2005 against Abbott and Central Glass, is pending in the
United Kingdom, High Court of Justice. A trial was held in December&nbsp;2006.
In another case, filed by Abbott and Central Glass in May&nbsp;2005 against
Baxter Company, Ltd., in the Tokyo District Court in Japan, Abbott obtained an
injunction against Baxter&#146;s sales of its products. Baxter has appealed that
decision. Two cases regarding a generic sevoflurane product sold by Cristalia
Productos Quimicos Farmaceuticos, Ltda. are pending in the Sao Paulo State
Court in Brazil.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Abbott is involved in litigation pending in the United
States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois related to Abbott&#146;s
patents for clarithromycin extended release (a drug Abbott sells under the </font></p>


 <p style="margin:18.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">16</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='16',FILE='C:\fc\5213854384_D11263_1741329\1583-1-dk.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Feb 21 13:09 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">trademark Biaxin&#174; XL) and
the proposed extended release products of the following companies: Andrx
Pharmaceuticals,&nbsp;Inc. (filed in March&nbsp;2005), and Sandoz,&nbsp;Inc.
(filed in September&nbsp;2005). In November&nbsp;2005, Abbott obtained a
preliminary injunction against Andrx preventing Andrx from launching its
extended release clarithromycin product. In January&nbsp;2007, the United
States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit affirmed the preliminary
injunction. In December&nbsp;2006, Abbott&#146;s motion for a temporary restraining
order against Sandoz was denied. In January&nbsp;2007, Abbott filed a motion
for preliminary injunction against Sandoz. Litigation relating to Abbott&#146;s
clarithromycin patents is also pending in Canada and South Africa.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">One case is pending in which Abbott seeks to enforce a
patent covering cefdinir (a drug that Abbott sells in the United States under
the trademark Omnicef&#174;). In October&nbsp;2006, Abbott was served with a
complaint filed by Lupin Limited in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern
District of Virginia alleging that one of the patents covering cefdinir is
invalid or not infringed by Lupin&#146;s generic product. Lupin also challenges the
validity of the patent term extension for this patent. Abbott is the exclusive
licensee of this patent, which covers the crystalline forms of cefdinir, in the
United States. In November&nbsp;2006, Abbott filed a counterclaim against Lupin
Limited and Lupin Pharmaceuticals,&nbsp;Inc. for infringement of this patent.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Twenty-one lawsuits, including fifteen purported class
actions, are pending against Abbott, Fournier Industrie et Sante, and
Laboratories Fournier, S.A. (Fournier), alleging antitrust and unfair
competition claims in connection with the sale of fenofibrate formulations. One
purported class action,<i> Paul T. Regan </i>(filed
in July&nbsp;2005), is pending in the United States District Court for the
Central District of California. The other fourteen purported class actions and
six individual actions are pending in the United States District Court for the
District of Delaware:<i> Alberto Litter</i>
(filed in August&nbsp;2005),<i> Allied Services
Division Welfare Fund and Hector Valdes</i> (filed in June&nbsp;2005),<i> American Sales Company,&nbsp;Inc. </i>(filed
in March&nbsp;2006),<i> Cindy Cronin</i>
(filed in July&nbsp;2005),<i> Diana Kim</i>
(filed in June&nbsp;2005),<i> Local 28 Sheet
Metal Workers</i> (filed in July&nbsp;2005),<i> Louisiana Wholesale Drug Company,&nbsp;Inc.</i> (filed in June&nbsp;2005),<i> Meijer,&nbsp;Inc.</i> (filed in June&nbsp;2005),<i> Painters District Council No.&nbsp;30 Health and
Welfare Fund</i> (filed in June&nbsp;2005),<i> Pennsylvania Employees Benefit Trust Fund</i> (filed in June&nbsp;2005),<i> Philadelphia Federation of Teachers Health and
Welfare Fund</i> (filed in July&nbsp;2005),<i> Elaine M. Pullman</i> (filed in June&nbsp;2005),<i> Rochester Drug Co-Operative,&nbsp;Inc. </i>(filed
in June&nbsp;2005),<i> Charles M. Shain</i>
(filed in July&nbsp;2005), and<i> Vista
Healthplan,&nbsp;Inc.</i> (filed in June&nbsp;2005),<i> CVS Pharmacy,&nbsp;Inc.</i> (filed in August&nbsp;2005),<i> Impax Laboratories</i> (filed in June&nbsp;2005),<i> Pacificare Health Systems,&nbsp;Inc.</i>
(filed in August&nbsp;2005),<i> Teva
Pharmaceuticals USA,&nbsp;Inc.</i> (filed in June&nbsp;2005), and<i> Walgreen Co.</i> (filed in June&nbsp;2005).
The plaintiffs seek actual damages, treble damages and other relief.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">A number of cases, brought as purported class actions
or representative actions on behalf of individuals or entities, are pending
that allege generally that Abbott and numerous other pharmaceutical companies
reported false pricing information in connection with certain drugs that are
reimbursable under Medicare and Medicaid and by private payors. These cases,
brought by private plaintiffs, the U.S. Department of Justice, State Attorneys
General, and other state government entities, generally seek monetary damages
and/or injunctive relief and attorneys&#146; fees. Abbott has filed or intends to
file a response in each case denying all substantive allegations. The federal
court cases have been consolidated for pre-trial purposes in the United States
District Court for the District of Massachusetts under the Multi District Litigation
Rules as <i>In re: Pharmaceutical Industry
Average Wholesale Price Litigation, MDL&nbsp;1456</i>. MDL&nbsp;1456
includes: (a)&nbsp;a purported class action case in which plaintiffs seek to
certify a nationwide class of Medicare Part&nbsp;B consumers and two
Massachusetts classes of third party payors and other consumers, filed in June 2003;
(b)&nbsp;eleven State Attorney General and five state county suits, including a
consolidated New York counties/City of New York suit filed in June&nbsp;2005;
and (c)&nbsp;a civil whistle-blower suit brought by the United States
Department of Justice (filed in federal court in the Southern District of
Florida in May&nbsp;2006). Abbott has filed a motion to dismiss the Department
of Justice case.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In addition, eight cases are also pending in state
courts: <i>State of West Virginia</i>,
filed in October&nbsp;2001 in the Circuit Court of Kanawha County, West
Virginia; <i>Swanston</i>, filed in March&nbsp;2002
in the Superior Court </font></p>


 <p style="margin:18.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">17</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='17',FILE='C:\fc\5213854384_D11263_1741329\1583-1-dk.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Feb 21 13:09 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">for Maricopa County,
Arizona; <i>International Union of Operating
Engineers</i>, filed in June&nbsp;2003 in the Superior Court of Monmouth
County, New Jersey; <i>Commonwealth of Kentucky</i>,
filed in September&nbsp;2003 in the Circuit Court of Franklin County, Kentucky;
<i>State of Texas</i>, filed in May&nbsp;2004
in the District Court of Travis County, Texas; <i>State
of Alabama</i>, filed in January&nbsp;2005 in the Circuit Court of
Montgomery County, Alabama; <i>State of Hawaii</i>,
filed in April&nbsp;2006 in the First Circuit Court of Hawaii; and the <i>State of South Carolina</i> (on behalf of the
State Health Plan), filed in August&nbsp;2006 in the Court of Common Pleas,
Fifth Judicial Circuit of Richland County. Certain state agencies, including
the Attorneys General of Florida and Idaho, are investigating Abbott&#146;s
marketing and pricing practices with respect to certain Medicare and Medicaid
reimbursable products. These civil investigations seek to determine whether
these practices violated any laws, including the Federal False Claims Act, or
constituted fraud in connection with the Medicare and/or Medicaid reimbursement
paid to third parties. While it is not feasible to predict with certainty the
outcome of the proceedings and investigations related to pricing information
for drugs reimbursable under Medicare and Medicaid, their ultimate dispositions
could be material to cash flows or results of operations for a quarter.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The United States Department of Justice, through the
United States Attorneys for the Eastern District of Wisconsin and the Western
District of Louisiana, are investigating the sales and marketing practices of
Kos Pharmaceuticals,&nbsp;Inc., a company Abbott acquired in December&nbsp;2006.
The United States Attorney for the Eastern District of Wisconsin is working
together with the Office of Inspector General of the United States Department
of Health and Human Services. In addition, the Louisiana U.S. Attorney is
investigating Kos&#146; calculation and reporting of Medicaid rebates. The
government is seeking to determine whether any of these practices resulted in
any violations of civil and/or criminal laws, including the Federal False
Claims Act, the Anti-Kickback Statute, and the Medicaid Rebate Statute in
connection with the Medicare and/or Medicaid reimbursement paid to third
parties.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In addition, the U.S. Department of Justice, through
the United States Attorney for Maryland, is investigating the sales and
marketing practices of Abbott for Micardis, a drug co-promoted with (until March&nbsp;31,
2006) and manufactured by Boehringer Ingelheim. The government is seeking to
determine whether any of these practices resulted in any violations of civil
and/or criminal laws, including the Federal False Claims Act, and the
Anti-Kickback Statute in connection with the Medicare and/or Medicaid
reimbursement paid to third parties.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Abbott is a defendant in numerous lawsuits involving
the drug oxycodone (a drug sold under the trademark OxyContin&#174;), which is
manufactured by Purdue Pharma. Abbott previously promoted OxyContin under a
co-promotion agreement with Purdue Pharma. Most of the lawsuits allege
generally that plaintiffs suffered personal injuries as a result of taking
OxyContin. A few lawsuits allege consumer protection violations and unfair
trade practices. One suit by a third party payor alleges antitrust pricing
violations and overpricing of the drug. As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, there are
a total of 123&nbsp;lawsuits pending in which Abbott is a party. Three cases
are pending in federal court and 120&nbsp;cases are pending in state court. 117&nbsp;cases
are brought by individual plaintiffs, and 6 cases are brought as purported
class action lawsuits. Purdue Pharma is a defendant in each lawsuit and,
pursuant to the co-promotion agreement, Purdue is required to indemnify Abbott
in each lawsuit.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Abbott is a defendant in several lawsuits originally
filed in the United States District Court for the District of Minnesota and
consolidated under the caption <i>In re Canadian
Import Antitrust Litigation</i> alleging generally that Abbott and
numerous other pharmaceutical manufacturers violated antitrust laws by
conspiring to prevent re-importation of drugs from Canada. The district court
dismissed with prejudice plaintiff&#146;s federal law claims and dismissed without
prejudice plaintiff&#146;s state law claims. In November&nbsp;2006, the Eighth
Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed the district court&#146;s decision.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">A case against Takeda Pharmaceutical Company Limited
and Takeda America Holdings,&nbsp;Inc. (&#147;Takeda&#148;) was filed in the United
States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois alleging Takeda
breached its fiduciary duty to Abbott in that Takeda is improperly diverting to
itself profits that </font></p>


 <p style="margin:18.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">18</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='18',FILE='C:\fc\5213854384_D11263_1741329\1583-1-dk.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Feb 21 13:09 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">rightly belong jointly to
Abbott and Takeda as equal joint venture partners in TAP Pharmaceutical
Products Inc. (owned 50&nbsp;percent by Abbott and 50&nbsp;percent by Takeda).
Abbott seeks injunctive relief and compensatory and punitive damages. In February
2006, the trial court granted Takeda&#146;s motion to dismiss, ruling that Abbott
must pursue its claim against Takeda in Japan. The U.S. Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit affirmed the dismissal.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In September&nbsp;2006, Johnson&nbsp;&amp; Johnson
filed a lawsuit against Guidant Corporation, Boston Scientific Corporation and
Abbott in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York
alleging that Abbott and Boston Scientific tortiously interfered with the
proposed merger agreement between Johnson&nbsp;&amp; Johnson and Guidant and
that Guidant breached that agreement. Johnson&nbsp;&amp; Johnson seeks monetary
damages. The defendants have filed motions to dismiss.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Abbott is a defendant in a class action lawsuit
pending in the United States District Court for the Northern District of
Illinois under the name <i>Myla Nauman, Jane
Roller and Michael Loughery v. Abbott Laboratories and Hospira,&nbsp;Inc.</i>
The plaintiffs are former Abbott employees who allege that their transfer to
Hospira,&nbsp;Inc., as part of the spin-off of Hospira, adversely affected
their employee benefits in violation of the Employee Retirement Income Security
Act, and that in their transfer, Abbott breached a fiduciary duty to plaintiffs
involving employee benefits. Plaintiffs generally seek reinstatement as Abbott
employees, or reinstatement as participants in Abbott&#146;s employee benefit plans,
or an award for the employee benefits they have allegedly lost. Abbott filed a
response denying all substantive allegations. Plaintiff&#146;s motion for class
certification on the breach of fiduciary duty claim is pending.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">A case is pending in the U.S. District Court for the
Northern District of California in which Medtronic Vascular,&nbsp;Inc.,
Medtronic USA,&nbsp;Inc., and Medtronic Vascular Galway, Ltd. (collectively
Medtronic) and Evysio Medical Devices ULC (Evysio) claim that Abbott&#146;s Multi-Link
Vision&#174;, Penta&#174;, Zeta&#174;, and Xience V Coronary Stent Systems infringe certain
Evysio stent design patents. Medtronic and Evysio seek damages, an injunction,
and other relief. Abbott has filed its response denying the infringement claims
and asserting that the patents are invalid and/or unenforceable. Evysio has
also brought lawsuits in France, Ireland (in which Medtronic is also a
plaintiff) and Germany claiming that the Vision&#174;, Penta&#174;, and/or Xience&nbsp;V
infringe the European counterparts of these patents. In France, a court
enjoined the launch of the Xience&nbsp;V stent. Abbott intends to appeal this
decision and has filed responses in each of these European courts denying the
infringement claims and asserting that the patents are invalid and/or
unenforceable. In the United Kingdom, Abbott filed an action seeking a
declaration that its stents do not infringe Evysio&#146;s patents and that the
patents are invalid. Evysio filed a counterclaim accusing Abbott&#146;s stents of
infringement and seeking a declaration of validity.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">A case is pending in the U.S. District Court for
Delaware brought by Advanced Cardiovascular Systems,&nbsp;Inc., now an Abbott
subsidiary, against Arterial Vascular Engineering,&nbsp;Inc. (now known as
Medtronic Vascular,&nbsp;Inc.) alleging that certain models of Medtronic&#146;s
stents infringe four of the company&#146;s Lau patents, and seeking injunctive
relief and damages. The court bifurcated the issues of liability and damages.
In February&nbsp;2005, a jury found that Abbott&#146;s Lau patents were valid and
infringed by all of the Medtronic stents in question, including its Driver&#174;
coronary stent. In June&nbsp;2005, the court held a hearing on Medtronic&#146;s
claim that the patents are unenforceable. The court has not rendered a decision
on this issue or on the parties&#146; post-trial motions and the issues of willful
infringement and damages have not been tried.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">While it is not feasible
to predict the outcome of such pending claims, proceedings and investigations
with certainty, management is of the opinion that their ultimate dispositions should
not have a material adverse effect on Abbott&#146;s financial position, cash flows,
or results of operations, except as noted above.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 47.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-47.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ITEM&nbsp;4.</font></b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>SUBMISSION
OF MATTERS TO A VOTE OF SECURITY HOLDERS<a name="Item4_SubmissionOfMattersToAVoteO_100847"></a></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">None.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:18.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">19</font></p>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='19',FILE='C:\fc\5213854384_D11263_1741329\1583-1-dk.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Feb 21 13:09 2007' -->



<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div>


<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">EXECUTIVE OFFICERS
OF THE REGISTRANT<a name="ExecutiveOfficersOfTheRegistrant_111624"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Executive officers of Abbott are elected annually by
the board of directors. All other officers may be elected by the board or
appointed by the chairman of the board. All officers are either elected at the
first meeting of the board of directors held after the annual shareholder
meeting or appointed by the chairman after that board meeting. Each officer
holds office until a successor has been duly elected or appointed and qualified
or until the officer&#146;s death, resignation, or removal. Vacancies may be filled
at any time by the board. Any officer may be removed by the board of directors
when, in its judgment, removal would serve the best interests of Abbott. Any
officer appointed by the chairman of the board may be removed by the chairman
whenever, in the chairman&#146;s judgment, removal would serve the best interests of
Abbott. A vacancy in any office appointed by the chairman of the board may be
filled by the chairman.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Abbott&#146;s executive officers, their ages as of February&nbsp;16,
2007, and the dates of their first election as officers of Abbott are listed
below. The executive officers&#146; principal occupations and employment from January&nbsp;2002
to February&nbsp;16, 2007 are also shown. Unless otherwise stated, employment
was by Abbott for the period indicated. There are no family relationships
between any corporate officers or directors.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Miles&nbsp;D. White, 51</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">2002 to present&nbsp;&#151;
Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer, and Director.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Elected Corporate Officer&nbsp;&#151; 1993.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Richard&nbsp;A. Gonzalez, 53</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">2006 to present&nbsp;&#151;
President and Chief Operating Officer, and Director.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">2002 to 2006&nbsp;&#151;
President and Chief Operating Officer, Medical Products Group, and Director.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Elected Corporate Officer&nbsp;&#151; 1995.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Richard&nbsp;W. Ashley, 63</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">2004 to present&nbsp;&#151;
Executive Vice President, Corporate Development.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">2002 to 2003&nbsp;&#151;
Senior Director, McKinsey and Company (a management consulting firm).</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Elected Corporate Officer&nbsp;&#151; 2004.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">William&nbsp;G. Dempsey, 55</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">2006 to present&nbsp;&#151;
Executive Vice President, Pharmaceutical Products Group.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">2003 to 2006&nbsp;&#151;
Senior Vice President, Pharmaceutical Operations.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">2002 to 2003&nbsp;&#151;
Senior Vice President, International Operations.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Elected Corporate Officer&nbsp;&#151; 1996.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Thomas&nbsp;C. Freyman, 52</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">2004 to present&nbsp;&#151;
Executive Vice President, Finance and Chief Financial Officer.</font></p>

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='23',FILE='C:\fc\52165650419_D11113_1742630\1583-1-dl.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Feb 21 16:57 2007' -->



<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div>


<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">PART&nbsp;II<a name="Partii_122604"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 47.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-47.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ITEM&nbsp;5.</font></b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>MARKET
FOR REGISTRANT&#146;S COMMON EQUITY, RELATED STOCKHOLDER MATTERS AND ISSUER
PURCHASES OF EQUITY SECURITIES<a name="Item5_MarketForRegistrantsCommonE_122604"></a></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Principal Market<a name="PrincipalMarket_122604"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
principal market for Abbott&#146;s common shares is the New York Stock Exchange.
Shares are also listed on the Chicago Stock Exchange and are traded on the
Boston, Philadelphia, and National Stock Exchanges, as well as on the NYSE Arca
and NASDAQ iM markets. Outside the United States, Abbott&#146;s shares are listed on
the London Stock Exchange and the Swiss Stock Exchange.</font></p>

</div>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Shareholders<a name="Shareholders_122611"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">There were 77,727&nbsp;shareholders
of record of Abbott common shares as of December&nbsp;31, 2006.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Dividends<a name="Dividends_122613"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Quarterly dividends of $.295 and $.275 per share were
declared on common shares in 2006 and 2005, respectively.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Abbott Laboratories is an
Illinois High Impact Business (HIB) and is located in a federal Foreign Trade
Sub-Zone (Sub-Zone&nbsp;22F). Dividends may be eligible for a subtraction from
base income for Illinois income tax purposes. If you have questions, please
contact your tax advisor.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">24</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
following graph compares the change in Abbott&#146;s cumulative total shareholder
return on its common shares with the Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor&#146;s 500 Index and
the Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor&#146;s 500 Health Care Index.</font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;">
 <tr style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="33" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:24.4pt;">
  <p align="left" style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;">Period</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="7" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:5.0pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="121" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:90.8pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.7pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="83" colspan="3" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:62.3pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;">(a)&nbsp;Total&nbsp;Number<br>
  of&nbsp;Shares<br>
  (or&nbsp;Units)<br>
  Purchased</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="82" colspan="4" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:61.3pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;">(b)&nbsp;Average&nbsp;Price<br>
  Paid&nbsp;per&nbsp;Share<br>
  (or&nbsp;Unit)</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="86" colspan="3" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:64.8pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;">(c)&nbsp;Total&nbsp;Number<br>
  of&nbsp;Shares<br>
  (or&nbsp;Units)&nbsp;<br>
  Purchased<br>
  as&nbsp;Part&nbsp;of&nbsp;Publicly<br>
  Announced&nbsp;Plan<br>
  or&nbsp;Programs</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">

  </td>
  <td width="29" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:21.8pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:6.5pt;position:relative;top:-3.0pt;">2</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.7pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

</div>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">1.</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>These shares
represent:</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 40.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(i)</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>the shares deemed
surrendered to Abbott to pay the exercise price in connection with the exercise
of employee stock options&nbsp;&#151; 60,859 in October; 145,747 in November; and
312,876 in December; and</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 40.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(ii)</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>the shares purchased on
the open market for the benefit of participants in the Abbott Canada Stock
Retirement Plan&nbsp;&#151; 13,000 in October; 13,000 in November; and 13,000 in
December.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">These shares do not
include the shares surrendered to Abbott to satisfy tax withholding obligations
in connection with the vesting of restricted stock or restricted stock units.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 20.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">2.</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>On October&nbsp;18,
2006, Abbott announced that its board of directors approved the purchase of up
to $2.5 billion of its common shares.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 47.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-47.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ITEM&nbsp;6.</font></b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>SELECTED
FINANCIAL DATA<a name="Item6_SelectedFinancialData_122710"></a></p>

  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">0.94</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.7pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr height="0">
  <td width="256" style="border:none;"></td>

</div>

<div style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><hr size="1" width="160" noshade color="black" align="left" style="width:120.0pt;"></div>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(a)</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Net sales for 2003 and 2002
have been adjusted to reflect the presentation of Hospira,&nbsp;Inc. as a
discontinued operation.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(b)</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>In 2006, Abbott recorded
pre-tax charges of $2,014 for acquired in-process and collaborations research
and development primarily related to the acquisition of Guidant&#146;s vascular
intervention and endovascular solutions businesses and Kos Pharmaceuticals,&nbsp;Inc.</p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">26</font></p>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='26',FILE='C:\fc\53123652282_D10967_1748696\1583-1-dm.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Feb 22 12:37 2007' -->



<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div>


<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 47.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-47.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ITEM&nbsp;7.</font></b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS<a name="Item7_ManagementsDiscussionAndAna_184429"></a></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Financial Review<a name="FinancialReview_184528"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Abbott&#146;s revenues are derived primarily from the sale
of a broad line of health care products under short-term receivable
arrangements. Patent protection and licenses, technological and performance
features, and inclusion of Abbott&#146;s products under a contract or by a pharmacy
benefit manager most impact which products are sold; price controls,
competition and rebates most impact the net selling prices of products; and
foreign currency translation impacts the measurement of net sales. Abbott&#146;s
primary products are prescription pharmaceuticals, nutritional products, vascular products and diagnostic
testing products. Abbott also owns 50 percent of TAP Pharmaceutical Products
Inc. that Abbott accounts for on the equity method.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The worldwide launch of <i>HUMIRA</i>, the acquisition of Guidant&#146;s vascular business, the
amendment of the Boehringer Ingelheim agreement, and the loss of patent
protection for some pharmaceutical products have impacted Abbott&#146;s sales, costs
and financial position over the last three years.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Pharmaceutical research and development is focused on
therapeutic areas that include immunology, oncology, neuroscience, metabolism,
and viral diseases. In 2003, Abbott began the worldwide launch of <i>HUMIRA</i>, which increased its worldwide
sales to $2.0 billion in 2006 compared to $1.4 billion in 2005. Substantial
research and development and selling support has been and continues to be
dedicated to maximizing the worldwide potential of <i>HUMIRA</i>. In December&nbsp;2006, Abbott acquired Kos
Pharmaceuticals which complements Abbott&#146;s existing franchise in the
dyslipidemia market and strengthens the late-stage and mid-term pharmaceutical
pipeline with opportunities in cholesterol management, asthma and inhaled
insulin. In 2005, Abbott and Boehringer Ingelheim (BI) amended their agreement
whereby Abbott distributed and promoted BI products. Effective January&nbsp;1,
2006, Abbott no longer distributed or recorded sales for distribution
activities for the BI products. Abbott&#146;s gross margins for BI products from the
prior agreement in effect through December&nbsp;31, 2005 were substantially
lower than its average gross margins. Sales of BI products were $150 million
and $2.3 billion in 2006 and 2005, respectively. In addition, increased generic
competition resulted in worldwide sales of clarithromycin declining 23 percent
in 2006.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2005 and 2006, Abbott&#146;s nutritional products businesses
were reorganized into a worldwide business to better leverage the opportunities
available for strong nutritional brands. Significant efforts have been focused
on capturing those opportunities, particularly in developing markets.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In April&nbsp;2006, Abbott acquired Guidant&#146;s vascular
intervention and endovascular solutions businesses and began to integrate it
with Abbott&#146;s vascular business. The acquisition significantly improved Abbott&#146;s
competitive position in this business that is characterized by rapid innovation.
In 2006, Abbott received European Union approval to market the <i>XIENCE&nbsp;V</i> drug eluting stent.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Abbott&#146;s diagnostic segment is comprised of four
separate divisions&nbsp;&#151; immunoassay/hematology, diabetes care, molecular, and
point of care. In early 2004, Abbott acquired TheraSense for $1.2 billion, and
began to integrate it with Abbott&#146;s diabetes care business. In January&nbsp;2007,
Abbott announced that it had agreed to sell its core laboratory diagnostics
business, including Abbott Point of Care, to GE for $8.13 billion in cash. Abbott
expects the sale to close in the first half of 2007. Abbott&#146;s Molecular
Diagnostics and Diabetes Care businesses are not part of this transaction and
will remain part of Abbott.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Abbott&#146;s short- and long-term debt totaled $12.4
billion at December&nbsp;31, 2006, largely incurred to finance recent
acquisitions. Operating cash flows in excess of capital expenditures and cash
dividends have allowed Abbott to fund acquisitions over the last three years.
At December&nbsp;31, 2006, Abbott&#146;s long-term debt rating was AA by Standard
and Poor&#146;s Corporation and A1 by Moody&#146;s Investors Service.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">27</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='27',FILE='C:\Fc\523392410_P66500CHE_1736055\1583-1-ea-01.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Feb 21 03:39 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2007, Abbott will focus
on several key initiatives. In the pharmaceutical business, Abbott will
continue the launch of newly approved indications for <i>HUMIRA</i>, and will also focus on the
integration of Kos Pharmaceuticals into the Pharmaceutical Products segment. Pharmaceutical
research and development efforts will continue to focus on the therapeutic
areas noted above with a significant portion of the development expenditures
allocated to new <i>HUMIRA </i>indications.
Abbott expects to submit additional pharmaceutical regulatory filings in 2007. In
the vascular business, Abbott will continue the launch of the <i style="text-transform:uppercase;">Xience</i><i> V</i> drug-eluting stent in Europe, and will launch in the U.S.
upon approval by the FDA. For diabetes care, Abbott anticipates the approval of
<i>FreeStyle Navigator</i>. Effort will
also be required for the sale and separation of Abbott&#146;s core laboratory and
point of care diagnostics businesses. In the other business segments, Abbott
will focus on developing or acquiring differentiated technologies in higher
growth segments of those markets.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Critical Accounting
Policies<a name="CriticalAccountingPolicies_184650"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font style="font-style:italic;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Sales
Rebates</font></i></font>&nbsp;&#151; Approximately 40 percent of Abbott&#146;s
consolidated gross revenues are subject to various forms of rebates and
allowances that Abbott records as reductions of revenues at the time of sale.
Most of these rebates and allowances are in the Pharmaceutical Products segment
and the Nutritional Products segment. Abbott provides rebates to pharmacy
benefit management companies, to state agencies that administer the federal
Medicaid and Medicare programs and the Special Supplemental Food Program for
Women, Infants, and Children (WIC), wholesalers, group purchasing
organizations, and other government agencies and private entities. Rebate amounts
are usually based upon the volume of purchases using contractual or statutory
prices for a product. Factors used in the rebate calculations include the
identification of which products have been sold subject to a rebate, which
customer or government agency price terms apply, and the estimated lag time
between sale and payment of a rebate. Using historical trends, adjusted for
current changes, Abbott estimates the amount of the rebate that will be paid,
and records the liability as a reduction of gross sales when Abbott records its
sale of the product. Settlement of the rebate generally occurs from two to
24&nbsp;months after sale. Abbott regularly analyzes the historical rebate
trends and makes adjustments to reserves for changes in trends and terms of
rebate programs. Rebates and chargebacks charged against gross sales in 2006,
2005 and 2004 amounted to approximately $2.6 billion, $2.5 billion and $2.4
billion, respectively, or 23.2 percent, 22.9 percent and 25.6 percent,
respectively, based on gross sales of approximately $11.0 billion, $10.9
billion and $9.3 billion, respectively, subject to rebate. A one-percentage
point increase in the percentage of rebates to related gross sales would
decrease net sales and operating earnings by approximately $110 million in 2006.
Other allowances charged against gross sales were approximately $247 million,
$284 million and $233 million for cash discounts in 2006, 2005 and 2004,
respectively, and $209 million, $162 million and $163 million for returns in
2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. Cash discounts are known within 15 to 30
days of sale, and therefore can be reliably estimated. Returns can be reliably
estimated because Abbott&#146;s historical returns are low, and because sales
returns terms and other sales terms have remained relatively unchanged for
several periods.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Management analyzes the adequacy of ending rebate
accrual balances each quarter. In the domestic nutritional business, management
uses both internal and external data available to estimate the level of inventory
in the distribution channel. Management internally estimates the inventory in
the retail channel that is not on the retail shelf. A third party continuously
measures time on the retail shelf, which is a relatively significant portion of
the time inventory is in the distribution channel. Except for a transition
period before or after a change in the supplier for the WIC business in a
state, inventory in the distribution channel does not vary substantially.
Management also estimates the states&#146; processing lag time based on claims data.
In addition, internal processing time is a factor in estimating the accrual. In
the WIC business, the state where the sale is made, which is the determining
factor for the applicable price, is reliably estimable. Estimates are required
for the amount of WIC sales within each state where Abbott has the WIC
business. External data sources utilized for that estimate are participant data
from the </font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">28</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='28',FILE='C:\Fc\523392410_P66500CHE_1736055\1583-1-ea-01.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Feb 21 03:39 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">U.S.&nbsp;Department of
Agriculture (USDA), which administers the WIC program, participant data from
some of the states, and internally administered market surveys. The USDA has
been making its data available for many years. Internal data includes
historical redemption rates and pricing data. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, Abbott
had the exclusive WIC business in 11 states.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In the domestic pharmaceutical business, the most
significant charges against gross sales are for Medicaid and Medicare Rebates,
Pharmacy Benefit Manager Rebates and Wholesaler Chargebacks. In order to
evaluate the adequacy of the ending accrual balances, management uses both
internal and external estimates of the level of inventory in the distribution
channel and the rebate claims processing lag time. External data sources used
to estimate the inventory in the distribution channel include inventory levels
periodically reported by wholesalers and third party market data purchased by
Abbott. Management estimates the processing lag time based on periodic sampling
of claims data. To estimate the price rebate percentage, systems and calculations
are used to track sales by product by customer and to estimate the contractual
or statutory price. Abbott&#146;s systems and calculations have developed over time
as rebates have become more significant, and Abbott believes they are reliable.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
following table is an analysis of the four largest rebate accruals<b>, </b>which comprise approximately 76 percent
of the consolidated rebate provisions charged against revenues in 2006. Remaining
rebate provisions charged against gross sales are not significant in the
determination of operating earnings. (<i>dollars
in thousands</i>)</font></p>

<div align="center">

  <td width="57" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:42.85pt;">

</div>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Adjustments for prior years&#146; rebate accruals have not
been material. Abbott employs various techniques to verify the accuracy of
claims submitted to it, and where possible, works with the organizations
submitting claims to gain insight into changes that might affect the rebate
amounts. For Medicaid, Medicare and other government agency programs, the
calculation of a rebate involves interpretations of relevant regulations, which
are subject to challenge or change in interpretation.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font style="font-style:italic;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Income
Taxes</font></i></font><font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;&#151; </font>Abbott
operates in numerous countries where its income tax returns are subject to
audits and adjustments. Because Abbott operates globally, the nature of the
audit items are often very complex, and the objectives of the government
auditors can result in a tax on the same income in more than one country.
Abbott employs internal and external tax professionals to minimize audit
adjustment amounts where possible. As part of Abbott&#146;s calculation of the
provision for taxes on earnings, Abbott records the amount that it expects to
incur as a result of audits. Each quarter, Abbott reviews its exposures in
accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards (SFAS) No.&nbsp;5, &#147;Accounting
for Contingencies.&#148; In the U.S., Abbott&#146;s federal income tax returns through
2003 are settled, and the income tax returns for years after 2003 are open.
Except for taxes on dividends that were remitted under the </p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">29</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='29',FILE='C:\Fc\523392410_P66500CHE_1736055\1583-1-ea-01.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Feb 21 03:39 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">American Jobs Creation Act
of 2004, Abbott does not record deferred income taxes on earnings reinvested
indefinitely in foreign subsidiaries. On January&nbsp;1, 2007, Abbott must
adopt the provisions of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;48 &#147;Accounting for
Uncertainty in Income Taxes&#148; which changes the measurement of tax contingencies.
Under this Interpretation, in order to recognize an uncertain tax benefit, the
taxpayer must be more likely than not of sustaining the position, and the
measurement of the benefit is calculated as the largest amount that is more
than 50&nbsp;percent likely to be realized upon resolution of the benefit. This
Interpretation will result in significantly more effort to assess tax
uncertainties than was required under SFAS No.&nbsp;5, and may result in
initial recording of tax expense that exceeds the expected resolution of tax
uncertainties. The adoption of this Interpretation is not expected to have a
material effect on Abbott&#146;s January&nbsp;1, 2007 balance sheet or the 2007
provision for income taxes.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font style="font-style:italic;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Pension
and Post-Employment Benefits</font></i></font>&nbsp;&#151; Abbott
offers pension benefits and post-employment health care to many of its
employees. Abbott engages outside actuaries to calculate its obligations and
costs under these programs. Abbott must develop long-term assumptions,
the most significant of which are the health care cost trend rate, discount
rate and the expected return on plan assets. The discount rates used to measure
liabilities as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005 were determined based on
high-quality fixed income securities that match the duration of the expected
retiree benefits. Prior to December&nbsp;31, 2005, the discount rate was
determined by reference to a composite corporate AA bond index. The health care
cost trend rate represents Abbott&#146;s expected annual rates of change in the cost
of health care benefits and is a forward projection of health care costs as of
the measurement date. A difference between the assumed rates and the actual
rates, which will not be known for decades, can be significant in relation to
the obligations and the annual cost recorded for these programs. Recent low
interest rates have significantly increased actuarial losses for these plans. At
December&nbsp;31, 2006, pretax net actuarial losses and prior service costs and
(credits) recognized in Accumulated
other comprehensive income (loss) for Abbott&#146;s defined benefit plans and
medical and dental plans were $1.4 billion and $537 million, respectively.
Actuarial losses and gains are amortized over the remaining service periods of
the employees under the corridor method, in accordance with the rules&nbsp;for
accounting for post-employment benefits. Differences between the expected
long-term return on plan assets and the actual annual return are amortized over
a five-year period. Footnote&nbsp;4
to the consolidated financial statements describes the impact of a one-percentage
point change in the health care cost trend rate; however, there can be no
certainty that a change would be limited to only one percentage point. On December&nbsp;31,
2006, Abbott adopted the provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;158 &#147;Employers&#146; Accounting
for Defined Benefit Pension and Other Postretirement Plans.&#148; The provisions of
this statement require the immediate recognition of the deferrals on the
balance sheet with a corresponding charge to Accumulated other comprehensive
income (loss). Adoption of this statement on December&nbsp;31, 2006 resulted in
a decrease in Abbott&#146;s shareholders&#146; equity of approximately $1.3 billion.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font style="font-style:italic;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Valuation
of Intangible Assets</font></i></font><font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;&#151;
</font>Abbott has acquired and continues to acquire significant intangible
assets that Abbott records at fair value. Those assets which do not yet have
regulatory approval and for which there are no alternative uses are expensed as
acquired in-process research and development, and those that have regulatory
approval are capitalized. Transactions involving the purchase or sale of
intangible assets occur with some frequency between companies in the health
care field and valuations are usually based on a discounted cash flow analysis.
The discounted cash flow model requires assumptions about the timing and amount
of future net cash inflows, risk, the cost of capital, and terminal values.
Each of these factors can significantly affect the value of the intangible
asset. Abbott engages independent valuation experts who review Abbott&#146;s
critical assumptions and calculations for significant acquisitions of
intangibles. Abbott reviews intangible assets for impairment each quarter using
an undiscounted net cash flows approach. If the undiscounted cash flows of an
intangible asset are less than the carrying value of an intangible asset, the
intangible asset is written down to its fair value, which is usually the
discounted cash flow amount. Where cash flows cannot be identified for an
individual asset, the review is applied at the lowest group level for which cash
flows are identifiable. Goodwill is reviewed for impairment annually or </p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">30</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='30',FILE='C:\Fc\523392410_P66500CHE_1736055\1583-1-ea-01.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Feb 21 03:39 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">when an event that could
result in an impairment of goodwill occurs. At December&nbsp;31, 2006 goodwill
and intangibles amounted to $9.4&nbsp;billion and $6.4&nbsp;billion,
respectively, and amortization expense for intangible assets amounted to $575&nbsp;million
in 2006. There were no impairments of goodwill in 2006, 2005 or 2004. At December&nbsp;31,
2006 the valuations for the Guidant and Kos acquisitions have not been
finalized.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font style="font-style:italic;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Litigation</font></i></font><i>&nbsp;&#151; </i>Abbott accounts for litigation
losses in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;5, &#147;Accounting for Contingencies.&#148;
Under SFAS No.&nbsp;5, loss contingency provisions are recorded for probable
losses at management&#146;s best estimate of a loss, or when a best estimate cannot
be made, a minimum loss contingency amount is recorded. These estimates are
often initially developed substantially earlier than the ultimate loss is
known, and the estimates are refined each accounting period as additional
information becomes known. Accordingly, Abbott is often initially unable to
develop a best estimate of loss, and therefore the minimum amount, which could
be zero, is recorded. As information becomes known, either the minimum loss
amount is increased, resulting in additional loss provisions, or a best
estimate can be made, also resulting in additional loss provisions.
Occasionally, a best estimate amount is changed to a lower amount when events
result in an expectation of a more favorable outcome than previously expected.
Except for one group of cases relating to pharmaceutical pricing for which
Abbott is unable to estimate a loss, if any, Abbott estimates the range of
possible loss to be from approximately $165&nbsp;million to $295&nbsp;million
for its legal proceedings and environmental exposures. Reserves of approximately
$200&nbsp;million have been recorded at December&nbsp;31, 2006 for these
proceedings and exposures. These reserves represent management&#146;s best estimate
of probable loss, as defined by SFAS No.&nbsp;5.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:20.0pt;"><font style="font-style:italic;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Stock
Compensation</font></i></font>&nbsp;&#151; Through December&nbsp;31, 2005,
Abbott measured compensation cost using the intrinsic value-based method of
accounting for stock options granted to employees and disclosed the impact of
the fair value method in the footnotes to the consolidated financial
statements. On January&nbsp;1, 2006, Abbott adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;123 (revised
2004), &#147;Share-Based Payment,&#148; which requires that fair value be recorded in the
results of operations. Since there is no market for trading employee stock
options, management must use a fair value method. There is no certainty that
the results of a fair value method would be the value at which employee stock
options would be traded for cash. Fair value methods require management to make
several assumptions, the most significant of which are the selection of a fair
value model, stock price volatility and the average life of an option. Abbott
has readily available grant-by-grant historical activity for several years in
its option administration system that it uses in developing some of its
assumptions. Abbott uses the Black-Scholes method to value stock options. The
results of the Black-Scholes model are periodically compared to the binomial
model and the results have been comparable. Abbott uses both historical
volatility of its stock price and the implied volatility of currently traded
options to develop the volatility assumptions. Abbott uses the historical grant
activity, combined with expectations about future exercise activity, to develop
the average life assumptions. Abbott has also used the historical grant data to
evaluate whether certain holders of stock options exercised their options
differently than other holders and has not found any differentiating pattern
among holders. Abbott quantified the additional paid in capital amount
available for use in determining tax effects of early exercise for measurement
of tax expense. Abbott used the modified prospective method of adoption. Under
this method, prior years&#146; financial results do not include the impact of
recording stock options using fair value. Footnote 9 quantifies the effect in
2005 and 2004 had compensation cost been determined using the fair value
method.</p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">31</font></p>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

Operations<a name="ResultsOfOperations_183413"></a></font></b></p>

for the last three years:</font></p>

  <td width="4" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:3.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="24" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:17.85pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">0.1</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="6" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:4.65pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="4" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:3.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="32" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:24.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">12.1</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="6" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:4.65pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="11" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:8.45pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="24" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:17.85pt;">

  </td>
  <td width="11" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:8.45pt;">

  <td width="6" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:4.65pt;">

 <tr>
  <td width="236" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:176.9pt;">

  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">

  <td width="26" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:19.75pt;">

  <td width="4" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:3.0pt;">

  <td width="24" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:17.85pt;">

  </td>
  <td width="6" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:4.65pt;">

  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">

  </td>
  <td width="4" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:3.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="32" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:24.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">8.9</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="6" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:4.65pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="11" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:8.45pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="24" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:17.85pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">7.4</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="11" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:8.45pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>

 <tr bgcolor="#CCEEFF">

 <tr>
  <td width="236" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:176.9pt;">

  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">

  <td width="4" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:3.0pt;">

  <td width="32" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:24.0pt;">

  </td>
  <td width="26" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:19.75pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="4" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:3.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

  <td width="24" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:17.85pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">3.2</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="6" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:4.65pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

  <td width="4" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:3.0pt;">
